messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Rutherford, Michael wrote:
>
> > In one example I tried was a fairly simple piece of business
logic. I needed
> > to write some tests around a user belonging to a group.
> >
> > I needed at a minimum an implementation of IDfUser and IDfGroup.
Due to the
> > nature of the beast it is most common to get these from the
session
> > (IDfSession). As all of these are interfaces it wasn't too bad
but each of
> > the interfaces extends others and have several hundred methods
each. I
> > eventually decided that what I was trying to test in this case was
> > Documentum logic and that I should just trust the framework.
> >
> > Another example is Documentum web components which are similiar
in some ways
> > to JSF. These extend standard Documentum classes which provide a
large
> > amount of functionality much of which eventually ties back to a
functionaing
> > sql database via a custom interface and/or query language. In
these cases
> > the best I could do was to test extracted business logic
piecemeal.
>
> I'm having difficulty seeing how these statements relate
to "various
> mocking libraries" having "too many moving parts to be useful for
more
> than trivial tests". It seems the problem lies in the Documentum
API and
> not in mocking libraries. What am I missing?

The "too many moving parts" comment was directed at my test code ie I
needed to add too much custom code to the mocks to allow them to talk
to each other as required. It is directly attributable to the
Documentum API and the interconnectedness of its many interfaces. It
has nothing to do with the usefulness of jmock etc.

Michael Rutherfurd
